Its major tenets are worship of nature and of the dead (animism), and also emphasizes an extended understanding of and respect for the lives, souls, and gods of one's ancestors, conceiving of these things as the essence of life, and whose material substance it is possible to know; it also views existence as divided between the Tokoyo (the spiritual world, the realm of gods, heaven and hell) and the Utsushiyo (this world, the realm of human beings), and also affirms the existence of Kinsokuchi, places where gods dwell (within whose hallowed borders one may not enter), as well as barriers that prevent crossing between the realms, and the efficacy of prayers and fortune-telling (shamanism), including in the determining of government policy, and finally in the creation of a mythology of the world and of human beings.

Although it has the base of primitive religion, it existed in Japanese culture for thousands of years and sublimated in many ways, in many regular vocations (occupations) before the Meiji period, and the principal of working hard was considered sacred as shown in Norito (Shinto prayer), and apart from Shinto rituals of Shrine Shinto, there are various ceremonies related to occupations which came from Shinto rituals and still exist in our society.

sen.e: Although at base Shinto is a primitive religion, it has existed in Japanese culture for thousands of years and now has very deep roots, becoming sublimated to the point that up until the Meiji period, most professions held as sacred the principle of hard work, just as expressed in the Norito (Shinto prayer), and even apart from the official rituals of Shrine Shinto, there are many work-related ceremonies even today that originally came from Shinto rituals.

sen.j: 仏教は本来、輪廻転生し徳を積めば最後は開眼し仏となる教えであり、「特定される個人としての死」はないので先祖崇拝はなく、「盂蘭盆」が正式な仏教行事で釈迦を奉るものである。
sen.e: The Buddhism originally has the belief that people become awakened and become god after reincarnate and cultivate virtue, there is no such thing as 'specified personal death' thus there is no need to worship ancestor, 'Urabon festival' is an official Buddhism ceremony to enshrine Shaka or Shkyamuni.

Buddhism originally has the belief that people become awakened and become gods after reincarnation and cultivate virtue, and there is no such thing as 'specified personal death' thus there is no need to worship ancestors, and the 'Urabon festival' is an official Buddhist ceremony to enshrine Shaka or Shkyamuni.

Originally, because Buddhism held that if people cultivated enough virtue over the cycle of rebirth, they would finally reach enlightenment and become Buddhas, there was no significance to any particular death of an individual and hence no ancestor worship, so in the beginning Urabon was an official Buddhist ceremony to revere Shakyamuni.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 現在では特定の仏教宗派に属さなければ、盂蘭盆にふれる機会は少ないことも、「お盆は仏教行事という認識」につながっている。
sen.e: Currently if someone does not belong to Buddhism school, he or she sill not have chance to experience urabon festival, which lead to the understanding of 'Obon festival is the Buddhist festival.'

Currently, if someone does not belong to a Buddhist school, he or she shall not have a chance to experience urabon festival, which leads to the understanding of 'Obon festival as the Buddhist festival.'
Today, if a person is not affiliated with any Buddhist sect, s/he will have little opportunity to participate in Urabon, which is why Obon is thought to be a specifically Buddhist festival.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

tit.j: 現世と常世・神域の結界と禁足地
tit.e: The current world and Tokoyo, the barrier of the holly precincts of a shrine and Kinsokuchi (tabooed land).
The current world and Tokoyo, the barrier of the holy precincts of a shrine and Kinsokuchi (tabooed land).
Kinsokuchi (hallowed ground) and the barriers between Utsushiyo (the current, physical world) and Tokoyo (the spirit realm) as well as the barriers around Shinto shrines
tit.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 自然に存在する依り代としての岩や山（霊峰富士山）・海や川などは、神の宿る場所でもあるが、常世と現世との端境であり、神籬の籬は垣という意味で境であり、磐座は磐境ともいい、神域の境界を示すものである。
sen.e: The natural place like rocks or mountain(holly Mt. Fuji) as yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) is where god stay, it is also boarder of Tokoyo and the current world,) the word of 籬 of himorogi (a temporarily erected sacred space or "altar" used as a locus of worship) means boarder, iwakura is also called iwasaka, the area deity sits which means the boarder of the the holly precincts of a shrine.

Natural places like rocks or mountains (holy Mt. Fuji) as yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) are where gods stay, and it is also a border between Tokoyo and the current world and the word 籬 of himorogi (a temporarily erected sacred space or "altar" used as a locus of worship) means border, and iwakura is also called iwasaka, the area that the deity sits, which means the border of the the holy precincts of a shrine.

As yorishiro that occur in nature, boulders and mountains (like holy Mt. Fuji) as well as seas and rivers are both places that the gods come to dwell and barriers between the spirit realm and the current (physical) world, and the "gi" from himorogi also means "fence", much as iwakura can also be called "iwasaka" (where "saka" means "border"); all these terms express the idea of the spritual boundary around a Shinto shrine.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 実際に「沖の島」のような神社や島や森林を含めた全体が禁足地としている場所も多くあり、その考えは神社神道にも引き継がれ、さまざまな建築様式のなかに内在もするが、例えば、本来は参道の真ん中は神の道で禁足となっている。
sen.e: In fact there are many places of Kinsokuchi (tabooed land) where the whole island with shrines and forests like 'Okinoshima island', this kind of idea was passed to Shrine Shinto and it exist in the various architectural method, for example, originally the middle part of sando (an approach to the temple) is considered as street for god and is Kinsoku. (not allowed to step on)

In fact, there are many locations of Kinsokuchi (tabooed land), involving the whole island with shrines and forests like 'Okinoshima island', and this kind of idea was passed to Shrine Shinto and it exists in the various architectural methods, for example, originally the middle part of sando (an approach to the temple) is considered as a street for god and is Kinsoku (not allowed to be stepped on).

In fact, there are many places--Okinoshima island, for example--whose entire area, including the shrines, the little islands, and the forests, are hallowed ground; this concept has been passed down to Shrine Shinto, and finds expression in the various building methods used in shrines, like for instance the fact that originally, the sando (the road that approaches the shrine) was for the gods, and as such no human was allowed to walk on it.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 結界は一般家庭にもあり、正月の注連縄や節分の「鰯の干物飾り」なども招来したい神と招かれざる神を選別するためのものでもある。
sen.e: Kekkai (barrier) exist in the general family, for example Shimenawa(sacred rice-straw ropes) and 'dried sardine decoration' of Setsubun (the traditional end of winter) was to select welcomed god and non welcomed god.

Kekkai (barrier) exist in the general family, for example Shimenawa (sacred rice-straw ropes) and 'dried sardine decoration' of Setsubun (the traditional end of winter) was to select welcome gods and not welcomed gods.

Symbolic barriers are still present in ordinary homes; for example, the shimenawa (holy straw cords) displayed around the new year and the ornaments made of dried sardines hung up for Setsubun (the holiday marking the end of winter, according to tradition) are intended to separate out the gods one wishes would visit from those one does not.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また、集落などをつなぐ道の「辻」には、石作りの道祖神や祠や地蔵があるが、旅や道すがらのの安全だけでなく、集落に禍や厄災を持ち込まないための結界の意味がある。
sen.e: There is stone statue of a travelers' guardian deity or a guardian deity of children on 'the crossroad' of the street connecting villages, these are not only for safety for the road or safety for traveling, but also for putting barrier on the road not to bring any disaster or misfortune to the village.

There is a stone statue of a travelers' guardian deity or a guardian deity of children on 'the crossroad' of the street connecting villages, and these are not only for safety for the road or safety for traveling, but also for putting barriers on the road so as not to bring any disaster or misfortune to the village.

Furthermore, small shrines, stone statues of the god who guards travelers, or statues of Jizo (the god of travelers and children) adorn the crossroads connecting villages; these are there not only to make the road safe and protect those traveling, but also to form barriers that can keep disasters or misfortune from affecting the village.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

tit.j: 祈祷や占いによる祈願祈念
tit.e: Prayer or fortunetelling
Prayer or fortunetelling
Prayer or fortunetelling

sen.j: 祈祷や占いは現在の神社神道でも受け継がれ、古来そのままに、亀甲占いを年始に行う神社もある。
sen.e: The prayer of fortunetelling were passed to the current Shrine Shinto and there are some shrines conduct fortune-telling by tortoiseshell of ancient style in New Year.
The prayers of fortune-telling were passed to the current Shrine Shinto and there are some shrines that conduct fortune-telling by using ancient style tortoiseshell at New Year.

Traditions concerning prayer and divination have been passed down to the modern-day Shrine Shinto, and there are still some shrines where tortoise-shell divination is still practiced at the new year, just as it was in ancient times.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 大正時代まで盛んであった弓矢も日本の価値観や文化（目星を付ける・的を射る・射幸心）に影響を与え、その年の吉凶を占うことから「矢取り」に選ばれたものは的場に足げく通ったという。
sen.e: The archery which was popular up to Taisho era also gave big influence to Japanese people's sense of value and the culture, (to target, shoot an arrow, speculative spirit) since people made fortunetelling of the year, it is said a person who was chosen as an arrow picker used to go to Matoba very often.

The archery which was popular up to the Taisho era also had a big influence on Japanese people's sense of value and culture, (to target, shoot an arrow, speculative spirit) since people made fortunetelling for the year, and it is said a person who was chosen as an arrow picker used to go to Matoba very often.

Japanese archery, which was popular up through the Taisho era, has also had a significant influence on the culture of Japan and the values of its people (as seen in terms like "to target," "to be on the mark" and "speculative spirit" (lit. "the hitting good fortune heart"), all of which derive from words used in archery), and because people determined the luckiness of each year by divination, the one selected to be "arrow taker" often went down to the "target area".
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 現在のおみくじも本来は神職による祈祷と占いを簡素化したものである。
sen.e: The current omikuji (sacred lots)is simplified form of original prayer and fortunetelling by Shinto priesthood.
The current omikuji (sacred lots)is a simplified form of the original prayers and fortunetelling by the Shinto priesthood.
Today's omikuji (fortune) is a simplified version, made by the Shinto priesthood, of the original prayers and divination.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また巫女の舞や庶民や芸能の芸として現在に受け継がれる「神事としての興行（相撲）」や舞（纏舞い・獅子舞）や神楽（巫女の舞など）や太神楽（曲独楽・軽業）なども神に捧げ神を和ぎ（かんなぎ）させるための祈りとしての祈祷である。
sen.e: Miko no mai (Shrine maidens dancing), or show enterprise (Sumo) as shinji (a divine service), Dance (Matoi dance (a dance using firemen's flags), shishimai (lion dance)), Kagura, a musical dance)(Miko no mai and so on), Daikagura (spinning tricks, acrobatics), which are all passed to the present as public entertainment for ordinary people and they were type of prayer to pray for god.
sen.cmt: 獅子舞, かんなぎ→定訳不明
sen.e: Miko no mai (Shrine maidens dancing), or show enterprise (Sumo) as shinji (a divine service), Dance (Matoi dance (a dance using firemen's flags), shishimai (lion dance)), Kagura, a musical dance) (Miko no mai and so on), Daikagura (spinning tricks, acrobatics), which were all passed to the present as public entertainment for ordinary people and they were a type of prayer to pray for god.

Moreover, Miko no mai (Shrine maidens' dance) as well as many kinds of entertainment among the common people and professional performers that have been passed down to the present day, including the "show business (Sumo) as Shinto ritual" or various kinds of mai (dance) like the Matoi (flaming flag) mai, shishi (lion) mai, Kagura (musical dances including Miko no mai) and Daikagura (spinning tricks and acrobatics), were originally types of ritual prayer intended to honor and appease the gods.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

tit.e: The politics, festival and enshrinement
The politics, festival and enshrinement
Government, festivals, and enshrinement
tit.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 古くは卑弥呼なども祈祷師であり、その祈祷や占いから「国の行く末」を決めていたと言われる。
sen.e: In ancient time, it is said Himiko was shaman and she used to make political decision for the 'destiny of the country' by conducting prayer or fortunetelling.
In ancient times, it is said Himiko was a shaman and she used to make political decisions for the 'destiny of the country' by conducting prayers or fortunetelling.
It is thought that many in ancient times, including Himiko, were actually shamans who made political decisions about the course the country should take based on prayer or divination.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 神社神道の神主などの神職は、古くから政（まつりごと）の執政をし、平安時代には道教の陰陽五行思想を取り込むことによって陰陽師という組織とその政治における官僚としての役職を得た。
sen.e: Shrine Shinto priest of Shirine Shinto used to do administration of government from old times, in the Heian period, they were able to obtain government official positions by using Inyo [Onmyo] gogyo shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Hsing Idea) of Taoism and by being belonged to the organization of Onmyoji" (diviner).

Shrine Shinto priests were involved in administration of government from old times, and in the Heian period, they were able to obtain government official positions by using Inyo [Onmyo] gogyo shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Hsing Idea) of Taoism and by being members of the organization of Onmyoji" (diviner).

Shrine Shinto priests have been involved in governance since ancient times, and in the Heian period, they incorporated the Taoist concept of Inyo (Onmyo) gogyo shiso (yin and yang and the Five Elements) into their beliefs and practices and in so doing, obtained official positions in the government as Onmyoji (masters of divination and sorcery).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: そして、占いや祈祷により指針を定め国政を司った。
sen.e: And they ruled the government by deciding policy by doing fortunetelling or prayers.
And they ruled the government by deciding policy by fortunetelling or prayers.
And so through their prayers and divinations, they were able to control the course of government policy.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: この流れは戦国時代 (日本)以降は潜むが公家の間では政として、あるいは神社神道として残っていった。
sen.e: This style was not popular during the period of civil war (Japan) but it remained as the government between cout nobles or as Shrine Shinto.
This style was not popular during the period of civil war (Japan) but it remained as the government between court nobles or as Shrine Shinto.
This sort of decision-making model fell out of vogue and lay dormant starting in Japan's Warring States period, but remained in use among the court nobility and among Shrine Shinto.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 地域振興の中心は古くは寺社であり、その中心にある神社が興行や縁日や神事を行い、「寺社普請」だけでなく地域の社会基盤整備としての普請も担った。
sen.e: In old days the regional promotion started from temples and shrines, the centre of this movement was shrines who conducted show enterprise, fair, Shinto rituals, they contributed into not only 'building temples and shrines', but also building the base of the social facility.

In the old days the regional promotion started from temples and shrines, and the centre of this movement was shrines which showed enterprise and followed Shinto rituals, and they contributed to not only 'building temples and shrines', but also building the base of society.

In ancient times most local development efforts were carried out by temples and shrines, and among such shrines, the focus was on entertainment, religious festivals, and Shinto rituals; their efforts were not limited only to building temples and shrines, but also extended to firming up societal infrastructure as well.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: そして民間でも自治としての政が江戸時代から一層顕著に認められ｛江戸時代以降の都心では町場（町奉行管轄）と庭場（寺社奉行管轄）と野帳場（検地がされていない管轄未定地や郊外）に区分され、庶民と町人が協力して自治を行った｝、祭りとして神や御霊や自然を祀り、その社会的行為は「七夕祭り」や「恵比寿講」として現在にも行われ、神社神道の儀式とは離れた民衆の神事として定着し、昔と同様に普請としての地域振興を担っている。
sen.e: And their role of ruling self-government in the society was well acknowledged especially from the Edo period, (after Edo period, the capital city was divided into Machiba (town) (Machi magistrate jurisdiction), Niwaba (jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) jurisdiction), Nochoba (the land with unknown jurisdiction or suburb which has not had land survey done), common people and townspeople cooperated each other to rule self-government), people enthroned god or spirits as festivals which can be seen events such as 'the Star Festival (celebrated on 'July 7 [August 7])' or 'festival in honor of Ebisu' and are passed to the present, they became people's Shinto rituals, not as part of the ceremony of Shrine shinto, they still contribute to construction for the regional promotion like old days.
sen.cmt: 町場、 町奉行→定訳不明
sen.e: And their role of ruling self-government in the society was well acknowledged, especially from the Edo period, (after the Edo period, the capital city was divided into Machiba (town) (Machi magistrate jurisdiction), Niwaba (jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) jurisdiction), Nochoba (the land with unknown jurisdiction or suburbs which had not had a land survey), and common people and townspeople cooperated with each other to rule by self-government), people enthroned god or spirits at festivals which can be seen at events such as 'the Star Festival (celebrated on 'July 7 [August 7])' or 'festival in honor of Ebisu' and were passed to the present, and they became the people's Shinto rituals, not as part of the ceremony of Shrine shinto, and they still contribute to regional life like in the old days.

And their method, in which even commoners practiced self government, received recognition, and indeed it became all the more striking starting in the Edo period (beginning in that period, large cities were divided into machiba (towns, under the jurisdiction of town magistrates), niwaba (jisha-bugyo, under the jurisdiction of (government-appointed) temples and shrine administrators), and nochoba (unsurveyed areas or suburbs of unfixed jurisdiction), and so commoners and townspeople cooperated to achieve self-government); the people used festivals to enshrine gods, spirits, and elements of nature itself, including such festivals as Tanabata (the Festival of the Weaver, celebrated July 7) and the Feast for Ebisu, both of which are still celebrated today, eventually becoming established as popular versions of Shinto rituals quite separate in form from Shrine Shinto rituals, but in any case, shrines continue to contribute to local development, even as they did in the past.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

tit.j: 現在に息づく古神道と勤しみの神聖
tit.e: Koshinto exist in the present and holly spirit of hard working.
Koshinto exists in the present and holy spirit of hard work.
Remnants of Koshinto that have survived to the present day, and the sacredness of hard work
tit.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: このように古神道は現在でも息づき、多くは民間信仰などとも言われるが、現在の神社神道の源流でもあり、本質でもあり、不可分であるといえる。
sen.e: Thus Koshinto still exist in the society, often it can be described as folk beliefs, this is the origin and the essence of the current Shrine shinto, but it is not explained well enough.
Thus Koshinto still exists in society and can often be described as folk belief, and this is the origin and essence of current Shrine shinto, but it is still not explained well enough.
Remnants of Koshinto can still be seen today, many of which can be termed "folk belief", but in fact Koshinto is the very origin and essence of Shrine Shinto, and as such is inseparable from it.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また、神社神道に対し生業（職業）としての神事があり、古くからの芸能・興行や農業・林業・水産業に限らず、鍛冶・多々良場（製鉄）や醸造・酒造や土木・建築といったように働く行為（いそしみ）自体に神が宿るとし神聖視してきた。
sen.e: There is also Shinto rituals as an occupation as opposed to Shinto Shinto, it was said that working itself had a spirit of god and was considered as holly act, working in occupations such as public entertainment, show enterprise, agriculture, forestry, fishery, blacksmith, iron making, brewing, civil engineering, architecture and so on.

There are also Shinto rituals as an occupation, as opposed to Shinto Shinto, and it was said that working itself had the spirit of god and was considered as a holy act, such as working in occupations such as public entertainment, show enterprise, agriculture, forestry, fishery, blacksmith, iron making, brewing, civil engineering, architecture.

Some Shinto rituals, unlike those of Shrine Shinto, actually developed into occupations, including such ancient practices as entertainment and show business, farming, forestry, and fishing but also extending to blacksmithing, iron smelting, sake brewing, public works, and construction; it was said of such jobs that in the act of working itself was something divine.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 現在でも伝統を引き継ぎ、「神棚」を備え行程の節目節目で神事としての儀式をおこなう職種は多くある。
sen.e: At present this tradition was passed on, there are many occupations, setting up 'household Shinto altar' in work place and have ceremony of Shinto rituals in each journey of starting new phase of the work.

At present this tradition has been passed on, and there are many occupations involving setting up of 'household Shinto altars' at the work place and have Shinto ritual ceremonies for each journey at the start of a new phase of work.

This tradition of hard work has been passed down to the present day, and many companies today choose both to erect small Shinto altars at their workplaces and to commemorate major turning points for the company with ceremonies featuring Shinto rituals.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 本来は神道とは、教義・教則のないものであり、古神道や「子作り信仰」や「寄り神信仰」などの民間信仰と神社神道を含め神道をわけ隔てる必要も無く、強いてその本質の共通性を上記の行為から汲み取るとすれば、己の心に対し「清く・正しく・美しく」あれということでしかないだろう。
sen.e: Originally Shinto means it has no doctrine or manual, there is no need to separate Shrine Shinto and Shinto from folk beliefs such as Koshinto, 'Kodukuri (having baby) belief' or 'Yorigami (attracting god) belief', if we have to find out the similarity of the essence from above mentioned act (between different belief), it is presumed that to become 'clean and beautiful and do the right thing' to our own mind.
sen.cmt: 子作り信仰, 寄り神信仰→定訳不明
sen.e: Originally, Shinto means it has no doctrine or manual, and there is no need to separate Shrine Shinto and Shinto from folk beliefs such as Koshinto, 'Kodukuri (having baby) belief' or 'Yorigami (attracting god) belief', if we have to find out the similarity of the essence from the above mentioned act (between different belief), it is presumed that to become 'clean and beautiful and do the right thing' to our own mind.

Originally, Shinto lacked any set doctrine or teaching method, which meant there was no need to differentiate Koshinto and folk beliefs in Kozukuri (baby-making) or Yorigami (god-summoning) from the rest of Shinto, including Shrine Shinto; if one constrains oneself to unearth the similarities that can be discovered in the above-mentioned actions, the only one that comes to mind is the concept that one must "purify, rectify, and beautify" one's heart.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

tit.j: 古神道と称する宗派とその変遷
tit.e: The religious school of Koshinto and the changes
The religious school of Koshinto and the changes
Religious sects and changes among them
tit.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 古来からの流れを汲む宗派と、江戸時代以降の後世に復古として取り入れた宗派がある。
sen.e: There were two religious school, one with ancient style and the other which was restored in the period after the Edo period.
There were two religious schools, one with ancient style and the other which was restored in the period after the Edo period.
There are two such sects, one whose form and style preserve the ancient ways and another which underwent a restoration beginning in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 宗派と変遷
sen.e: The religious school and the changes
The religious school and the changes
Religious sects and changes among them
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代末期に、古神道と称する思想や儀礼などが、尊皇攘夷思想や平田国学の隆盛と連動して、世に出たものが多くあるが、しかし当時の記録文書は無きに等しく、原始仏教同様、実際には後世の資料などから、間接的に推理・類推される存在に過ぎないことも指摘されている。
sen.e: There were many thoughts or ceremonies of Koshinto came to the society in the late Edo period when the the thought of Sonno Joi (slogan advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners) and Hirata Kokugaku became popular, however there was not many historical record available, similar to primitive Buddhism, it is appointed that it can only be presumed or make analogical inference from materials in later period indirectly.

There were many thoughts or ceremonies from Koshinto that were introduced to society in the late Edo period when the thoughts of Sonno Joi (slogan advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners) and Hirata Kokugaku became popular, however there are not many historical records available, similar to primitive Buddhism, and it is indicated that it can only be presumed, or can only make analogical inference from materials of later periods indirectly.

Many concepts and ceremonies from Koshinto were introduced into Japanese society during the late Edo period, their popularization tied to the rise of both the sonno joi (revere the Emperor, expel the barbarians) philosophy and the Hirata school of Kokugaku, but few historical records detailing Koshinto influence survive today, so much like the case of primitive Buddhism, it seems it is in fact only possible to make inferences on Koshinto based on later documents or by analogy.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 明治時代以降は仏教やキリスト教と同じ範疇の宗教ではなく国家儀礼と位置付けられるようになった国家神道に対し、宗教であることを色濃く打ち出したのが古神道であった。
sen.e: After the Meiji period, State Shinto was considered as national ceremony which was separated from the religion of Buddhism and Christianity, on the other hand Koshinto had strong religious background.

After the Meiji period, State Shinto was considered as a national ceremony which was separated from the religions of Buddhism and Christianity, on the other hand Koshinto had a strong religious background.

Beginning in the Meiji period, Koshinto--in contrast to State Shinto, which was classified as a series of civil ceremonies and thus as different from other religions like Buddhism or Christianity--was marked by a much stronger sense of religiosity.

On this point, Koshinto is very similar to late Edo-period Shinto sects, notably the Kurozumikyo sect, and indeed, quite a few people choose to describe Sect Shinto's religious organizations as Koshinto.

In traditional Koshinto, there was ceremony or gyoho (method of ascetic practices) which was succeeded from Hakke-Shinto of Imperial Shinto, Atsutane HIRATA worked as Gakuto (head student), there are other Gyoho or religious styles that exist which came from Izumo Shinto, Kannagi Shinto, Kukami Shinto, Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).

In traditional Koshinto, ceremonies and gyoho (ascetic practices) that had been passed down from Hakke Shinto branch of Imperial Shinto, one of whose head students was Atsutane HIRATA; but other gyoho and religious groups were handed down, not from the Hakke branch but from Izumo Shinto, Kannagi Shinto, Kukami Shinto, or Shugendo (a type of mountain asceticism).
